data.title: Issue with dynamic content providers and reference ui (and more)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.5.0-insider (1.5.0-insider)` 1de4d832ccb061c13cf70eaf0221fbaa86abfbdd
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G31)`

I'm working on a new extension to provide CodeLens for Git across most supported vscode languages (assuming they implement a DocumentSymbolProvider. But I've run into a few bugs as well as API (and UI) limitations.

You can find my [GitLens](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens) extension on GitHub with the latest release [here](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/releases/tag/0.0.3). I haven't yet wanted to publish it to the marketplace until I get some of these issues resolved.

Here are a couple of screenshots to give you an idea of the UI:

Provides CodeLens with the author and date of the last check-in.

> ![CodeLens](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eamodio/vscode-git-codelens/master/images/preview-codelens.png)

Clicking on a CodeLens opens a blame "explorer" with the commits and changed lines in the right pane and the commit (file) contents on the left.

> ![Blame Explorer](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eamodio/vscode-git-codelens/master/images/preview-blame.png)

Let me first say that I know I am really stretching the limits (read: hijacking) the reference UI, but I think it does come pretty close to something pretty cool for this.

The first biggest issue I've been running into is using a `TextDocumentContentProvider` to provide the content for a reference location url seems to time out after a minute or so -- seems like it is getting garbage collection, but I'm not sure how to stop that.

Next issue is I would like to provide decorators (blame line indication) for the content provided by my `TextDocumentContentProvider`. I've been able to hack this the first time the my [GitBlameContentProvider](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/master/src/gitBlameContentProvider.ts) is loaded for a particular uri, but once it is cached there doesn't seem to be any published event that I can trap to trigger a decoration. It would be really nice if there was an even when a reference was selected in the reference UI. It would also be great if there was a way to officially find a particular uri in the visible set of editors -- right now I have this[ awful hack](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/master/src/gitBlameContentProvider.ts#L75).

I would also love to be able to control the order (and initial selection) of locations provided to the reference UI -- right now they are sorted alphabetically, so I am resorting to crafting my uris with an [embedded index](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/master/src/gitProvider.ts#L140) -- which is less than ideal. Also the initial selection of the reference UI seems to be the location closest to the trigger point in the document, but I would love to be able to control that -- even for real references it is arguable if that is ideal.

I thought I was also seeing race conditions with the Omnisharp-vscode extension, where the C# `DocumentSymbolProvider` wouldn't respond when my CodeLens would try to execute `vscode.executeDocumentSymbolProvider`. I haven't been able to really reproduce this lately, so it could be gone now.

Thank you for the awesome product that vscode is and I would greatly appreciate any help or guidance on these issues!

Thanks,
Eric Amodio

data.title: Keyboard word selection does not include the space and is inconsistent with other editors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: any
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Enter a string of words in the editor, such as "Today is going to be a good day."
2. Click anywhere in the sentence and select a word using Ctrl+Shift+Right Arrow.

The selection should include the word and the following space, if it exists.  This behavior is pretty standard in Windows applications, including the OS itself (try the "start>run" box), Microsoft Word and Visual Studio.  Since VSCode behaves differently in this regard, it results in excessive keyboard navigation and selection mistakes.

data.title: tweet feedback box should not treat Twitter as the only first class means of communication
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6
### Kind Words

Though I agree with issue [#7893](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7893), I support the existence of the feedback box. As a new software, this is an easy way to acquire immediate feedback. As a new user, this is a quick way to give feedback.
### Complaint

But some users do not participate in social media. This feedback box emphasizes Twitter for communication.
### Suggestion
- The links within the "Other ways to contact us" should be turned into sibling buttons to the Tweet button i.e. a GitHub "Issue" and/or "Request" button.
- There should be a button to provide positive feedback that does not require a social media account, perhaps a button that is equivalent to a `mailto:` hyperlink on a webpage.

data.title: Subproject adds don't always show up in the git pane

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
After looking dumb in bf77eac, I noticed that subprojects can be silently committed from the git pane. I had cloned those repos there so they would light up in the built version of VS Code.
1. Open a folder containing a git repo in VS Code
2. Clone another repo into that folder
3. Click the refresh button in the git pane - nothing shows up
4. Make a change in another file
5. Commit that change (without first staging the file)

Examine the actual commit, and see that it also contained the second repo added as a subproject.

If you stage the new file first, then the subprojects aren't added.

Deleted subprojects are shown in the git pane.

data.title: Eagerly show tab or Preview Editor when using "Quick open"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When using Quick Open or editor stack `ctrl+tab`, the tab should be eagerly be selected so a visual context of the content can be seen below the quick open view pane.  

While navigation the view with your arrow keys, if selected editor tabs were open, they would be switched to, hitting escape would return to the tap you initiated the action on, hitting return would in effect keep you on the tab that was being eagerly shown (through open tabs or the Preview Editor).

This is very helpful to find the file you're planning to open.  It's heavily used feature of mine from ST3.

![image](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/397c67e42200857d1efc2d5b294e2bd36b2c24a4/68747470733a2f2f662e636c6f75642e6769746875622e636f6d2f6173736574732f38323433372f313638363736332f30356136666433362d356465632d313165332d383035302d6463623637343030643632312e676966)
- VSCode Version: 1.5 insider
- OS Version: macOS

refs: https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/issues/5

data.title: Editor selection colors should be simplified

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (1de4d832ccb061c13cf70eaf0221fbaa86abfbdd, 2016-08-31T06:16:16.953Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-36-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Follow up from #1636

I think we need to take a step back and take a good look at editor selection colors. Currently there are so many states, it's very confusing as to what find match, selection match is what and even what the actual selection is.

Here are some of the states using my theme [Glacier](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Tyriar.theme-glacier):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149502/4d7a8d04-6f95-11e6-8726-a4df8ee95627.png) Selection
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149492/32a2bbe6-6f95-11e6-985b-d2de3a32ed5a.png) Find match
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149524/765a9340-6f95-11e6-94a6-9d916a2af65a.png) Symbol match
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149531/8b5d273a-6f95-11e6-9096-b713c7f04233.png) Selection match (lighter than word match)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149574/ca1a92d2-6f95-11e6-90d9-31c18dbab87d.png) Selection + selection match
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149882/e9ed2942-6f97-11e6-912c-0638a2225c4a.png) Selection + find match + symbol match
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149620/0fc5e642-6f96-11e6-940a-3990cf650c9d.png) Symbol highlight
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149599/e9b7ff26-6f95-11e6-8403-bfc48f88d79e.png) "Strong" symbol highlight for cursor word
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149654/55266e00-6f96-11e6-89ab-d4be281a65a7.png) "Strong" symbol highlight for words away from cursor
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149744/e5b605b6-6f96-11e6-9a1e-b9a27d5832f4.png) Selection + "Strong" symbol highlight for cursor word
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149762/02f6e762-6f97-11e6-82d2-8746528ed790.png) Selection + "Strong" symbol highlight for cursor word (when selecting via <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>d</kbd>)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18149836/8b8ef84e-6f97-11e6-89d0-48dfb0fc87db.png) Selection + "Strong" symbol highlight for cursor word (when selecting via <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>d</kbd>) + Find match

This is in no way an exhaustive list of states but I think it gets the point across. Here are some of my initial thoughts:
- The _actual_ selection should _always_ be the selection color defined in the theme - this is the primary reason I sometimes lost my selection.
- Find matches should _not_ use the selection color defined by the theme.
- Some of these states have colors that differ by so little they lose information and make the UI look sloppy. We should reduce the number of possible colors by reducing the amount they can stack with each other.
- Is it useful differentiating symbol highlight and selection highlight?
- Is strong symbol highlight useful? We already have a color to indicate symbols and they can't both show at once.
  - I'm quite perplexed by it, especially when things like this happen:
    
    ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18150034/ef49b940-6f98-11e6-8b92-760f40dd5c4d.png)
    
    Why are both `userEnv` variables highlighted with the strong symbol highlight below but not above?
    
    ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/18150039/fd69d172-6f98-11e6-83f4-b495607ae9ca.png)
  - The blue looks bad in my theme, is there a way we can get a more suitable color using existing colors?
- The line highlight color doesn't work when a range is selected.
- Can we use a border to indicate find matches or something? That would make the distinction very clear.
- Since 95% of themes are just imported from Sublime `.tmTheme` files and not adjusted to work better with vscode, we should make an effort to have the defaults work and only add additional tmTheme properties if they are absolutely necessary.
- `findHighlight` is defined in many themes, why don't we adopt that since Sublime uses it?

Personally I think something like below would be more usable despite being so simple (this is to illustrate my point, I'm not proposing this):
- Selection is always the `selection` color from theme
- All symbol and word highlights are `selection` color at 50% opacity
- Find matches use white with 50% opacity

data.title: Filename completion for imports?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.6

I haven't been able to figure out if VS Code will do file/path completion when using ES2015 `import`. It seems like it doesn't (it should IMO). Once I've typed in a path, I can cmd-click it to jump to the file, which is great, _except_ if the import is an absolute path, e.g.:

```
import { something } from '/rootlevel/this/that';
```

Then VS Code has no idea what that file is. Is there some way to get this working?

data.title: <enter> in an empty debug console produces 'undefined'

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 7 Professional Version 6.1 (Build 7601: Service Pack 1)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. From command prompt type 'code --list-extensions'

Instead of the extensions being listed the GUI opens.

I've tried this with my normal group of extensions installed and with no extensions installed, the results are the same.

Also, I've made sure there are no Code.exe processes still running and I've rebooted between attempts. 

The behavior is also identical on my home system which is also Windows 7.

data.title: Custom Icon for symbols
data.body: It there any plan to support the ability to add custom icons in Symbols navigations? Sometimes the provided one do not really fit your needs and not all the things can be categorised as `Class` `Namespace`, `Structure` and so on!

data.title: Typos in files.autoSave comment
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.5.0
- OS Version:Windows 10

// Controls auto save of dirty files. Accepted values:  "off", "afterDelay", "onFocusChange" (editor looses focus), "onWindowChange" (window looses focus). If set to "afterDelay" you can configure the delay in "files.autoSaveDelay".
"files.autoSave": "off"

looses -> loses
missing comma

Should be:
// Controls auto save of dirty files. Accepted values:  "off", "afterDelay", "onFocusChange" (editor loses focus), "onWindowChange" (window loses focus). If set to "afterDelay", you can configure the delay in "files.autoSaveDelay".

data.title: VS Code delays file save operation

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version:  Mac 10.11.6
## Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create file watcher via (gaze, chokidar) on a source file that is open in VS Code and run it.
2. Let the document be idle in VS Code for a few minutes. Important.
3. Save the document.
## Expected:

File watcher to notice the file change immediately.
## Actual:

File changes are noticed a few seconds later (up to 10 seconds). But if you make subsequent changes, they are noticed almost immediately.

At first I thought it was gaze's fault, then I tried chokidar, then I tried chokidar in polling mode, they all behaved the same way. But when I `touch`ed the files they are always immediately noticed.

Which means...

The problem seems to be VS Code delaying the save operation. I've looked through whole code path and couldn't find the culprit myself unfortunately.
## Why is it important?

Because when you are trying to see the result of automated tests and they are delayed, it is really annoying.

data.title: Provide a homeDir system variable for use in launch.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version:  OSX 10.10 and OSX 10.11

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Folow tutorials on creating .vscode/launch.json 
2. Set paths that start at the Home Directory (eg: %USERPROFILE% on Windows, $HOME / ~ on Linux)

It would be nice to have a `homeDir` system variable to use in the Launch.json.  I have been using the ruby plugin and I have looked over a number of examples, issues and tutorials.  One thing that strikes me is that the launch.json looses some utility if it is not reusable.  Take for example the RSpec launch that I am working through now while using RVM on a Mac:

```
        {
            "name": "RSpec - all",
            "type": "Ruby",
            "request": "launch",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/rspec",
            "useBundler": true,
            "pathToBundler": "/Users/<username>/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.3.0/wrappers/bundle",
            "showDebuggerOutput": true,
            "pathToRDebugIDE": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/rdebug-ide",
            "args": [
                "-I",
                "${workspaceRoot}"
            ]
        },
```

While this works:

`"pathToBundler": "/Users/<username>/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.3.0/wrappers/bundle",`

It would be much easier/shareable/reusable to have:

`"pathToBundler": "${homeDir}/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.3.0/wrappers/bundle",`

Similar to what is available for `workspaceRoot`.  

I speculate the complexity here would come in from working for all OS's. (eg: %USERPROFILE% on Windows, $HOME / ~ on Linux).
